basic_data.name: Four Seasons Centre for the Performing Arts

description: Canada's first purpose-built opera house was completed in 2006 and is the home of the Canadian Opera Company and the National Ballet of Canada. Highlights of the Four Seasons Centre include the world's longest freespan glass staircase and a horseshoe-shaped, European style auditorium featuring phenomenal advancements in modern engineering and acoustical design. Facility tours are available. For upcoming opera and ballet performances, visit the Canadian Opera Company and The National Ballet of Canada websites.

reviews.title: Shen Yun at Four Seasons Centre - NOT what I expected or wanted
text: The show was divided into a series of short stories, some funny, some poignant, all beautifully performed. However, at least one third of the show was designed to promote falun gong (falun dafa). I have nothing against this or any other religion. However, I very much resent being lured in to see a dance troupe, only to find that a lot of the show was to promote falun gong. If I had known in advance, I would NOT have gone.

reviews.title: Loved La Boheme
text: Lovely venue to see La Boheme by Puccini. We already loved the music but the orchestra, stage sets, and wonderful singing were amazing! Highly recommend.

reviews.title: consider listening to the mp3 instead: the visual component is consistently missing
text: Operas here used to be among the best in the world, in my opinion – and I have seen many performances all around the world. In the past several year the quality dramatically changed, mostly for the visual component. The orchestra is still superb, and the voices are mostly decent, but the decoration of the set is so minimalistic that one better stays home and listen to mp3 for free and not pay 200$ per ticket. This visual deprivation was done by the Canadian Opera House to even most classic operas that normally bring a great visual impression, in addition to the sound – Aida, Barber of Seville, Carmen, Marriage of Figaro and now Macbeth. All these great operas in their latest production now have the same black&grey & brown decor, simplistic and depressive. Barocco operas are stripped of their visual components entirely; characters are in business suits on semi-empty stages. Macbeth also was economizing on lightning so badly that we barely saw what was happening, and having the whole stage in the dark grey and brown, with all characters dressed in black or dark grey in such poor light doesn’t help. Considering that majority of patrons in the audience have grey-hair age, proper light and color contrasts are important. Late arrivals who were offered to watch the opera on the screen told me that it was so dark picture that it was no point in looking at the screen. Only when it was curtain time, and there was a bit more light, we could see that the characters’ boots looked blue – the color was completely missed during the performance. Plus the female choir and the lead female singer really struggled during the latest performance – I was surprised that this choir was out of synch and power. Normally the COC "delivers" the sound. Male singers were all superb, and so was the orchestra. However, looking at consistently black-grey-brown design that the new director prefers I now wonder if we have to continue our membership there. Yes, Macbeth opera is dark, but it is the responsibility of the director to make sure that the characters are visible, contrasted with each other and from the background, as their behaviour and facial expression in the scene are part of the story. Here not only was colour contrast missing, plus a deficit of light made it difficult to see the details, but the main characters looked alike, had the same beards, hairstyles, and clothing – so it was hard to trace who was who (with exception of the last group in red).

reviews.title: Shen Yun
text: Beautiful place. Our seats were 388-392, ring 3. Excellent seats except 388 which was partially blocked by stage lighting. I was able to move the chair which made it slightly better. Very strange how a relatively new theatre would have partially obscured views. Other than that really cool place,  great sound as well.

reviews.title: Fun at the Four Seasons
text: The centre was clean and had strict practices still in place which was appropriate for the diverse audience being served. Washrooms are downstairs, there are elevators for those who need it. YOu can purchase items and pick them up after your show-highly recommended.

reviews.title: At last: opera has returned to the Four Seasons Centre
text: The hall was custom built for opera, and returning to it after a Covid-caused hiatus of more than two years was wonderful. We attended a performance of La Traviata, the best we've seen and heard in several years, including performances in Venice and Berlin. Amina Edris was an effective Violetta; her voice and acting were both very fine. Matthew Polenzani and Simone Piazzola were also excellent as Alfredo and his father. The production was free of directorial quirks of the kind that are as likely to irritate as delight. A splendid afternoon!

reviews.title: Great place to see a show
text: This was our first time to this theatre and it is quite modern and the sightlines are excellent.  We were there for a Friday evening performance of The National Ballet of Canada’s Sleeping Beauty and we sat in the front row of the third level and loved seeing the full orchestra in addition to the dancers from our seats.  The theatre is also home to the Canadian Opera Company and although we have never been to the opera the building might convince us to attend, especially if we could see Pagliacci!  Located on hip Queen Street West only doors away from Planta on Queen and Marvelous by Fred there is plenty to do both before and after a production!

reviews.title: Nutcracker ballet
text: Hubby and I attended the Nutcracker ballet for a Sunday 5:30pm performance.  Vaccination verification was easy and quick.  Ushers knew exactly where to direct us for our seats. Coat check was $3 per person without issues.  Theater was clean. Seats were relatively comfortable. We would definitely return for a future show.

reviews.title: Gorgeous place
text: I went there to see Shen Yun show every year. Excellent sound effect, stunning view from any angle.  The dancers and music are perfectly melted together.

reviews.title: Wonderful experience
text: We went to watch the ballet at this theatre. It's a spacious place with a swanky interiors. Great place to go for theatre performances.

reviews.title: Wow
text: We saw The Sleeping Beauty by the National Ballet and were not disappointed with the performance or the amazing venue. My only regret was despite having a decent view, we were far from the stage and in future would definitely spend more money on seats closer to the stage.

reviews.title: Great night seeing the National Ballet
text: Saw Sleeping Beauty at the Four Seasons. Even though our seats were in the upper ring section, the view was good (if distant) and the acoustics were great.

reviews.title: Overpriced - but good for concerts, dance shows etc.
text: We went there to watch Shen Yun. It is a great theater overall. Big seating capacity and the acoustics are very well designed to give an amazing experience. However, the height adjustment between the two rows could have been a little more. This is a good place for dance shows and music concerts etc but not for plays. Small theaters are the best for that. The tickets are quite expensive - especially in case of Shen Yun, we found it overpriced, but then that's the case with most of the theaters where the price is based on the quality of the venue rather than the quality of the show.
They have a coat check and washrooms one floor below. Not too sure about the parking since we just took an Uber. However, plenty of taxis and Ubers available around this area.

reviews.title: National Ballet Nutcracker Suite
text: Lovely venue-comfortable seats with room. Easy to get to with public transit and ticket pricing is reasonbable

reviews.title: Not a single mirror within the wardrobe area…
text: You have to pay extra for a wardrobe. While this is common in north america, I still consider it to be very inappropriate for an opera house.
Also, guess what? There are no mirrors(!) in the wardrobe downstairs.
As for opera performance – I’m not an expert, hence no comment.

reviews.title: Great theatre
text: I attended the Sheyun dance yesterday. the theatre set and lay out is great. it is open space so I enjoyed the show. comfortable seats. the theatre has 4 seating area. it is shaped in semi-circle which is making it really convenient to see the show on the stage. I recommend it but however the parking lot in basement are thiefs in disguise. has flat rate of $10 but in event they put up the price as they know you have to attend. I ended up paying $22 for 4 hrs parking. I recommend parking close by then attend theatre.

reviews.title: Great Acoustics but Expensive Food
text: It was our very first time to set foot at this venue which is the home of the Canadian Opera Company. The most stunning structure of this venue are the stairs which can be seen from outside the glass panelled building. Inside the theatre the seats are a bit narrow and are not as comfortable as I would expect them to be. Acoustics was fine. The sound of the orchestra in the Nutcracker Performance was not loud but was just appropriate for the performance. My only complaint about the food and drinks in Torontos theatres is that they are so expensive. A small water bottle costs $4 which is like buying a water bottle in Iceland or Paris.

reviews.title: Great acoustics
text: Not the most impressive facility from the outside but every performance I have seen has been outstanding.  The National Ballet is phenomenal and well worth the visit.

reviews.title: An outstanding concert hall in the center of town
text: The Four Seasons Centre for the Performing Arts is a modern hall that houses the Canadian Opera Company and the National Ballet of Canada. It accommodates over 2000 spectators and its modern design fits into the theme of downtown Toronto. Equipped with all modern necessities, this theater can accommodate small productions and the largest operatic creations. The acoustics are exquisite and there is not a bad seat in the house. During our recent stay, we were able to enjoy an excellent production of Arabella as well s a delicate and original performance of Swan Lake. Both productions were well planned and performed.

reviews.title: Very nice modern center centrally located
text: We had the opportunity to go se Tosca and  it was a great production.  We really enjoyed the theater as well as it is very modern and it is pleasant to walk around before the performance or at intermission.

reviews.title: High Culture of Fantasy
text: Attended a performance of The Dream, a ballet of Shakespeare Midsummer Night Dream with music by Mendelssohn and choreography by Ashton. It was a magical night centered in a green forest full of faeries and their royalty, human couples chasing each other, an imp playing games with all including turning a man into a donkey. Using a green forest stage where all the action and characters chased each other, the audience were immersed in a forest fantasy escaping reality for awhile suspended in high culture recreation of a dream courtesy of National Ballet artistry and talent. Sartre Being and Nothingness was set in a broken home taken apart while couples intimacies were spied on by men in black, music by Glass, choreography by Cote.

reviews.title: First Class Venue
text: Fabulous bright open building, excellent acoustics and good sight lines.  I love the seats on the stairs for pre show events.

reviews.title: Wonderful Eugene Onegin
text: The venue itself is superb, surely one of the best opera houses in North America, and ranking with the best anywhere. Our seats at the side of the third ring gave an excellent view of the stage. The performance of Eugene Onegin was a delight, with very strong performances by Gordon Bintner as Onegin, Joseph Kaiser as Lenski, and Joyce El-Khouri -- all three are Canadian! -- as Tatiana. The production, originally designed by Robert Carsen, another Canadian, for the Met, is spare and very effective. The performance was considerably more enjoyable than Hadrian, which we saw and heard the week before, and which we found more than a little disappointing in spite of the fine singing.

reviews.title: Amazing structure for the performing arts
text: Great acoustics.. no matter where you sit..
We just came back from seeing premier of Hadrian.. amazing performance.
I loved the left balcony seating we had..  We got to see the full orchestra pit, stage etc..

and seats were cheaper the the grand ring..  & for those that don't need to pay the high prices of a seat.. there is also standing room available on night of a performance which we were able to get for a friend who wanted to attend last minute..
Love the building.. Love the theatre.. Had an amazing time..

reviews.title: A Marriage of math, engineering, acoustics & honest beauty.
text: Exposed structural glass beams, steel connectors, bowed wood, all celebrate the purity of the materials in an unpretentious way. This sets the stage for whats to come, but also helps to set each guests in an atmosphere where the chosen dress, weather modern simple lines or haute Couture, each is set in a space which transforms each person into works of art. A design masterpiece! The acoustics, speaks of flawless math & in motion, creating a warm envelope of musical notes that cradles you in a full body embrace. The show you see will be different from what i saw, so I'll only comment on my experience of the space. Standing room tickets were available the night of the show, & dare i say, if you r looking for a last minute world class experience its worth the $12. (we got one for a last minute addition to our group in the balcony box, there was an empty seat so she was able to sit with us even though they stated that even if a seat is empty she could not sit. no one cared or checked)  Overall it was a wonderful experience worth driving 4 hrs into Toronto.

reviews.title: Great venue
text: We attended the opera and being New Yorkers we compare everything to what is available at home. The Four Seasons Centre for the Performing Arts is a wonderful performance space. Upon arriving the staff, which is plentiful, is helpful in directing newcomers to areas and seating. Inasmuch as we decided at the last minute to try to get tickets we were fortunate to find seats which were very good. The acoustics were also good. The building is centrally located.

reviews.title: First Ballet
text: I thought I'd add some "culture" into my life by attending my first ballet; but no. I think this will be my first and last. I wanted to surprise my wife with this special event, but as much as I enjoyed the facility, I did not enjoy the ballet.
Overall the Four Seasons Centre is well designed, clean and would love to visit to watch another type of event. It's very close to a subway station and good hotels.
But, I would choose another event to attend next time I visit this location.

reviews.title: Toronto’s ballet and opera performing space
text: A beautiful interior with excellent sound and sight lines.  Worth making reservations for the Canadian Opera Company and the National Ballet of Canada

reviews.title: World class
text: Visitors to Toronto, here you can see world class,singers at better prices.  Alas, the opera season is ending but remember , next season is something to look forward to.  If you get a chance to see Sondra Radvonovsky in Anna Bolena   GO

The singing is perfection .  The production ?   Well rather static and lumpen    The opera house , however, built on a tight budget is beautiful   Worth the visit alone.  Acoustics? Well it's tweaked a bit unlike the Met.     Every visit to the Canadian Opera Company is a privilege

reviews.title: Wow this place is spectacular!
text: My family and I attended a performance of the Nut Cracker on Christmas Eve.  The venue itself is just beautiful and the atmosphere was perfect for Christmas Eve.  While we were waiting for our daughter we sat in the little coffee shop, then went to the gift shop which is very nice as well.  The performance itself was spectacular and first class all the way from the dancing to the costumes...everything was truly amazing. Really looking forward to going back.

reviews.title: Beautiful glass building
text: It is a modern, glass sparkling building, with a lot of space inside and with an excellent acoustics. I recently visited the Four Seasons Center for a ballet performance. I really liked the theatre shop in a large bright lobby with a large selection of ballet goods (books, decorations, T-shirts...) and lovely Christams tree decorated with pointe shoes. You could also buy ballet shoes signed by dancers from the National Ballet of Canada there. The seats were comfortable and the ambience very nice. I had an amazing time there.

reviews.title: Nutcracker Ballet
text: Stunning venue for the Nutcracker ballet. We sat in the third ring and had a great view. We used the refreshment lounge on the second level and washrooms were clean and handy as well. We parked at Nathan Phillips square underground parking and it was much less than other garages. Will definitely return for other performances at the Four Seasons Performing Arts Centre.

reviews.title: Perfect Christmas afternoon :: the nutcracker
text: It is a stunning building that invites you for enjoyment. We decided to go for the nutcracker performance and it was delightful. They had a storyteller that introduced the story to the children. Everything worked smoothly. Staff is friendly and competent. Acoustics are good not great and if you can afford it don’t get tickets above 4th ring.

reviews.title: Best opera experience
text: I love Opera so Four Seasons Center is one of my favourite places. It is an opera house with one of the best acoustics in the world. You can see here world class Opera Productions. Best singers , amazing Orchestra.

reviews.title: Great Acoustics
text: We saw Dvořák's Rusalka here a few weeks ago and were really impressed with the acoustics. The venue has a really warm and welcoming atmosphere and the lobby really accentuates this.

reviews.title: Ballet/Opera
text: This is a stunning venue, very classy! Luv the pre talks before the ballet, you can pre order a drink or snack for pick up, we donate to the ballet and have access to the “Friends Lounge” That helps avoid washroom line ups. Opera’s are also amazing to experience here as well. For those just attending an event for one night you won’t be disappointed. Ask if there is a pre- talk. Enjoy!

reviews.title: Beautiful Theater
text: Love attending the opera here.  Attended Otello on opening night.  Wonderful experience made enjoyable by the subtitles.  Nice facility.

reviews.title: Home of the Canadian Opera Company
text: This performing arts Centre is centrally located and is at the subway.  It is the home of the Canadian Opera Company.  The house is comfortable, attractive, with good acoustics.  It is walking distance to many hotels and restaurants.  It is also on the PATH, the underground shopping Centre in the downtown core.

reviews.title: Impressive Arts Center
text: The Four Seasons Center is a modern, glass sparkling construction for the Performing Arts. Dance and Opera are presented on alternating schedules. It houses the Canadian Opera Company and the National Ballet of Canada.
I recently visited the Center for a ballet performance.  And liked the theater very much.
The Box Office staff was very nice when I went earlier in the day to pick up my ticket.
During intermission there was food and drinks at the bar. Sandwiches, cakes, sweets, Champagne, Wine, Beer,.
I’ll definitely plan to return soon for more performances.

reviews.title: The Nutcracker
text: Just attended the matinee performance of the Nutcracker on December 08, 2018. I highly recommend this attraction that continues through to December 30, 2018 whether you are a fan of the ballet or not. A fine example of modern day theatrical magic and wonder for all ages. Easy access in the heart of Toronto by nearby TTC subway university line at the corner of University and Queen St w. If you prefer to drive, there is parking available in the parking garage entry from York St. We were able to park inside, and leave our coats in the car, walk through the warm parking garage and take the elevator up to the theater entrance. There is a large bright lobby with some areas to sit and relax before the doors open to the theater. Refreshment is available and you can pre-order for the intermission.
